It is defined to be Boltzmann's constant times the natural log of the total number of states of a system. Gibbs free energy is calculated from subtracting enthalpy by temperature times this quantity. For 10 points, name this measure of the disorder of a system, which tends to increase over time in a closed system.

tossups.text: The Sackur-Tetrode equation can be used to obtain this quantity for ideal gases. One definition can be found by multiplying the logarithm of the multiplicity of a macrostate by Boltzmann's constant. If this quantity reaches a maximum, the universe may experience heat death. Maxwell's Demon can cause a decrease in this quantity, which is stated to always increase by the Second Law of Thermodynamics. For 10 points, name this quantity represented by S that in thermodynamics can refer to the measure of disorder in a system.

tossups.text: For a black hole, this quantity is given by the product of the area of that black hole with Boltzmann's constant, divided by four times the Planck length squared. Taking the negative derivative with respect to temperature of the Helmholtz free energy yields this quantity, which can be defined as Boltzmann's constant times the logarithm of the number of microstates of a system. This quantity goes to a minimum as temperature approaches absolute zero. For 10 points, the second law of thermodynamics holds that, over time for isolated systems, there is an increase in what measure of disorder, symbolized S?
tossups.answer: entropy [prompt on S before it is read]

For monoatomic ideal gases, this value is calculated by the Sackur-Tetrode equation. (*) Maxwell's Demon is able to decrease this value without expending work. The Second Law of Thermodynamics suggests that this value has an "arrow of time," because it always increases over time. For 10 points, what amount of energy unable to perform work is the measure of disorder in a system?

texts: Name this property which, for water at room temperature, equals about 24 torr.

Traditionally, the vapor pressure in the Clausius–Clapeyron equation is normalized either to one bar or one of these units. At this pressure, a liquid boils at its normal boiling point. You are currently experiencing roughly this much pressure.

The Clausius–Clapeyron equation is derived using a Maxwell relation relating "dP dT" to a derivative involving these two other quantities. The differentials of these two extensive quantities appear in the definition of internal energy.
answers: vapor pressure [or saturation pressure; or P-sat; or P-star; prompt on partial answer; prompt on P]
one atmosphere [or atmospheric pressure; or one atm; or P-atm]
entropy AND volume [or S AND V; or molar entropy AND molar volume] <Silverman>

This theorem establishes limits for data compression, showing that if n random variables are encoded in fewer than n times the entropy of the variables, there is a high risk of information loss. The average length of the best possible compression is the entropy divided by the logarithm of the number of possible symbols.

This method of data compression can usually halve the size of the original file. It encodes by searching for the shortest substring not in its dictionary, and then pulling out the next longest and adding that to the dictionary.
answers: Shannon's source coding theorem or noiseless coding theorem or Shannon's second theorem
